results.query: Compare Mining and Manufacturing indices for 2023-24
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear comparison of Mining vs Manufacturing indices for 2023‚Äì24, based on the Index of Industrial Production (IIP), Base Year 2011‚Äì12, from MoSPI data:

üìä IIP Comparison: Mining vs Manufacturing (2023‚Äì24)
Sector	IIP Index	Growth Rate (%)
Mining	128.9	7.5%
Manufacturing (overall)	(varies by industry)	Mixed / modest
üîç Key Insights
‚õèÔ∏è Mining

Strong performance in 2023‚Äì24

IIP Index: 128.9

High growth of 7.5%, indicating robust expansion

Reflects higher output in minerals, likely supported by infrastructure demand and energy needs

üè≠ Manufacturing

Uneven performance across sub-sectors

Growth was modest to weak overall, with several industries contracting

Examples from manufacturing sub-sectors:

üìà Food Products: +1.6%

üìà Beverages: +5.1%

üìâ Tobacco Products: ‚Äì8.3%

üìâ Wearing Apparel: ‚Äì14.1%

üìâ Paper & Paper Products: ‚Äì3.6%

‚û°Ô∏è This shows that while a few segments grew, many manufacturing industries faced slowdown or contraction, pulling down overall performance.

üßæ Overall Comparison (One-line takeaway)

Mining significantly outperformed Manufacturing in 2023‚Äì24, with much stronger growth and a healthier index level, while manufacturing showed patchy and subdued growth.

If you want, I can also:

Compare this with 2022‚Äì23

Show trend charts

Focus on core manufacturing only

Link this performance to GDP or infrastructure spending

Just tell me üëç

results.query: Show Primary Goods, Capital Goods and Intermediate Goods performance in 2022-23
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs the official MoSPI (IIP, base year 2011-12) performance of Primary, Capital, and Intermediate Goods in 2022-23 üëá

Index of Industrial Production (Use-based categories)
Use-based Goods	IIP Index (2022-23)	Growth Rate (%)
Primary Goods	139.2	7.5%
Capital Goods	100.3	13.1%
Intermediate Goods	149.4	3.8%
Quick interpretation

Capital Goods showed the strongest growth (13.1%), indicating a solid pickup in investment and capacity creation.

Primary Goods grew at a healthy 7.5%, reflecting steady performance in basic industrial inputs.

Intermediate Goods grew more moderately (3.8%), suggesting relatively softer momentum in supply-chain inputs compared to capital formation.

If you want, I can:

Compare this with 2021-22 üìä

Show a trend over multiple years

Convert this into a chart or exam-ready answer (UPSC/State PCS style)

results.query: What's the trend for Mining, Electricity and General index from 2020-21 to 2023-24?
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs the trend overview based on MoSPI‚Äôs Index of Industrial Production (IIP, base year 2011-12) for the period 2020-21 to 2023-24. Even without getting into every sub-number, the broad movement across the three indices is quite clear:

üìä Overall Trend (2020-21 ‚Üí 2023-24)
ü™® Mining Index

2020-21: Sharp contraction due to COVID disruptions, lockdowns, and supply-chain breaks.

2021-22: Strong rebound as restrictions eased and demand for core industries picked up.

2022-23: Continued expansion, supported by coal, limestone, and metal ore production.

2023-24: Further improvement, with mining index reaching ~129 and a healthy positive growth (~7‚Äì8%), showing sustained momentum.

‚û°Ô∏è Trend: üìâ ‚Üí üìà ‚Üí üìà ‚Üí üìà
(from contraction to steady recovery and growth)

‚ö° Electricity Index

2020-21: Mild decline / stagnation during lockdown period.

2021-22: Recovery as industrial and commercial demand revived.

2022-23: Strong growth driven by higher power consumption, heat waves, and industrial usage.

2023-24: Growth continues, though at a more stable and moderate pace compared to the rebound year.

‚û°Ô∏è Trend: üìâ ‚Üí üìà ‚Üí üìà ‚Üí ‚ûñüìà
(recovery followed by stabilization at a higher level)

üè≠ General Index (Overall IIP)

2020-21: Significant dip due to economy-wide shutdowns.

2021-22: Sharp rebound (base effect + reopening).

2022-23: Growth moderates but remains positive.

2023-24: Steady expansion, reflecting normalization and more balanced industrial growth.

‚û°Ô∏è Trend: üìâ ‚Üí üìà ‚Üí ‚ûñüìà ‚Üí ‚ûñüìà
(V-shaped recovery, then steady growth)

üîç Big Picture Takeaway

2020-21 was the clear low point across all indices.

2021-22 marked a strong recovery year.

2022-23 and 2023-24 show stabilization with sustained growth, especially in Mining and Electricity.

Industrial activity has largely normalized above pre-COVID levels by 2023-24.

If you want, I can also:

Put this into a clean comparison table, or

Add year-wise index numbers and growth rates, or

Compare this with pre-COVID (2018-19) levels for deeper context.

results.query: Compare Consumer Durables vs Consumer Non-durables across all available years
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clean, data-backed comparison of Consumer Durables vs Consumer Non-durables across all available years from the Index of Industrial Production (IIP), base year 2011-12.
(Data source: MoSPI IIP ‚Äì Use-based classification)

1. Long-term level comparison (Index values)

Big picture:

Consumer Non-durables consistently have a higher index level than Consumer Durables.

This reflects their essential nature (food, FMCG, daily-use items) versus discretionary spending on durables.

Year	Non-durables Index	Durables Index
2012-13	106.1	104.9
2015-16	117.2	119.1
2018-19	145.5	130.4
2019-20	145.3	119.0
2020-21	142.1	101.2
2022-23	147.7	114.5
2024-25	151.4	128.0

üìå Insight:
Non-durables show steady, structural growth, while durables fluctuate more with the business cycle.

2. Growth rate comparison (volatility vs stability)
Consumer Durables

Highly volatile

Sharp contractions during stress periods

Strong rebounds when demand returns

Key years:

2020-21: -15.0% (pandemic shock)

2021-22: +12.5% (pent-up demand)

2024-25: +7.9% (recovery momentum)

Consumer Non-durables

Much more stable

Smaller downturns, quicker normalization

Key years:

2020-21: -2.2%

2023-24: +4.1%

2024-25: -1.5%

üìå Insight:
Durables behave like a cyclical demand play, while non-durables act as a defensive consumption anchor.

3. Crisis performance (COVID stress test)
Year	Non-durables Growth	Durables Growth
2019-20	-0.1%	-8.7%
2020-21	-2.2%	-15.0%
2021-22	+3.2%	+12.5%

üìå Insight:

Non-durables cushioned the industrial sector during COVID.

Durables suffered deeper falls but delivered stronger rebound growth.

4. Structural takeaway

Consumer Non-durables

Higher base

Lower volatility

Reflect income stability & population growth

Acts as a stabilizer for IIP

Consumer Durables

Lower base

High sensitivity to:

Income expectations

Credit conditions

Interest rates

Acts as a leading indicator of consumer confidence

Bottom line

Non-durables = stability + scale
Durables = volatility + growth optionality

If you want, I can also:

Plot this visually üìä

Compare pre- vs post-

results.response_text:
Got it üëç
Here are the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) figures for the use-based categories you asked for, with base year 2011-12 = 100, straight from MoSPI.

Use-based IIP (Annual)
2021‚Äì22

Infrastructure / Construction Goods

Index: 148.2

Growth rate: 18.8%

Capital Goods

Index: 88.7

Growth rate: 16.9%

Intermediate Goods

Index: 143.9

Growth rate: 15.4%

2022‚Äì23

Infrastructure / Construction Goods

Index: 160.7

Growth rate: 8.4%

Capital Goods

Index: 100.3

Growth rate: 13.1%

Intermediate Goods

Index: 149.4

Growth rate: 3.8%

Quick takeaway

Infrastructure/Construction Goods showed strong momentum in both years, though growth moderated in 2022‚Äì23.

Capital Goods crossed the base-year level (100) in 2022‚Äì23 ‚Äî a positive sign for investment activity.

Intermediate Goods growth slowed sharply in 2022‚Äì23, hinting at softer input demand.

If you want, I can also:

put this into a clean table (Excel-style)

compare with Primary Goods / Consumer Goods, or

link this to GDP or capex trends for analysis üìä

results.query: How is mining, manufacturing, electricity and primary goods doing in 2023-24?
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear snapshot of how the key industrial sectors performed in 2023‚Äì24, based on MoSPI‚Äôs Index of Industrial Production (IIP, base year 2011‚Äì12). I‚Äôll keep it sector-wise and policy-relevant.

1. Mining

Performance: Strong

IIP growth: +7.5% in 2023‚Äì24

Index level: ~129

What‚Äôs driving it

Strong demand from steel, power, and infrastructure

Higher output of coal and key minerals

Government push on infrastructure and energy security

‚û°Ô∏è Mining was one of the better-performing core sectors this year.

2. Manufacturing

Performance: Mixed, but resilient overall

Manufacturing showed uneven growth across industries:

Strong performers

Basic metals: +11.6%

Pharmaceuticals: +8.0%

Electrical equipment: +7.5%

Machinery & equipment: +6.6%

Non-metallic minerals (cement, etc.): +6.5%

These benefitted from:

Infrastructure spending

Capex recovery

Export demand in select segments

Weak or contracting segments

Wearing apparel: ‚Äì14.1%

Computer, electronic & optical products: ‚Äì11.3%

Tobacco products: ‚Äì8.3%

Paper products, wood products: mild contraction

‚û°Ô∏è Capital-goods and heavy industries did well, while consumer-facing and export-dependent segments lagged.

3. Electricity

Performance: Positive and stable

(From IIP sectoral classification)

Electricity output grew steadily, supported by:

Higher coal availability

Rising industrial and commercial demand

Summer-driven consumption

‚û°Ô∏è Electricity continued its role as a supporting backbone for industrial growth.

4. Primary Goods

Performance: Healthy

Primary goods (use-based category) benefited from:

Strong mining output

Stable electricity generation

Infrastructure-linked demand

‚û°Ô∏è Growth in primary goods aligns with the investment-led growth pattern seen in 2023‚Äì24.

Big Picture Takeaway

Mining and primary goods: strong momentum

Manufacturing: uneven, but capex-linked industries did well

Electricity: steady and supportive

Growth pattern remains investment- and infrastructure-led, not consumption-led yet

If you want, I can:

Compare this with 2022‚Äì23

Link these trends to GDP or employment

Break it down into use-based categories (capital, consumer, intermediate goods)

Mining and Quarrying

Manufacturing

Electricity, Gas, Water Supply & Other Utility Services

Construction

Trade, Hotels, Transport, Communication & Services Related to Broadcasting

results.query: Compare all use-based categories for the year 2018-19
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear comparison of all Use-based IIP categories for 2018-19 (Base Year: 2011-12), based on official MoSPI data üìä

Use-based Categories: 2018-19 Comparison
Use-based Category	IIP Index	Growth Rate (%)
Infrastructure / Construction Goods	141.7	7.3
Consumer Non-durables	145.5	4.0
Consumer Durables	130.4	5.5
Primary Goods	126.1	3.5
Intermediate Goods	126.2	0.9
Capital Goods	108.4	2.7
Key Takeaways üîç

Infrastructure / Construction Goods were the best performer, showing the highest growth (7.3%), reflecting strong activity in construction and infrastructure projects.

Consumer Durables (5.5%) grew faster than Consumer Non-durables (4.0%), indicating relatively stronger demand for big-ticket consumer items.

Capital Goods had the lowest index (108.4) and modest growth (2.7%), pointing to slower investment momentum.

Intermediate Goods showed very weak growth (0.9%), suggesting subdued industrial input demand.

Primary Goods grew moderately, in line with basic industrial activity.

If you want, I can:

Compare this with earlier or later years

Show a trend analysis

Or relate these categories to overall industrial growth or GDP

results.query: What was the performance of General index, Mining, Manufacturing, Capital Goods and Consumer Durables in 2017-18?
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs the performance of the selected IIP indices in 2017‚Äì18 (Base year: 2011‚Äì12), as reported by MoSPI:

Index of Industrial Production (IIP), 2017‚Äì18
Sector / Category	Index Level	Growth Rate (%)
General Index	125.3	4.4
Mining	104.9	2.3
Manufacturing (overall)	126.6	4.6
Capital Goods	105.6	4.0
Consumer Durables	123.6	0.8
Quick interpretation

Overall industrial production (General Index) grew by 4.4% in 2017‚Äì18.

Manufacturing slightly outperformed the general index with 4.6% growth, remaining the main driver of industry.

Mining grew modestly at 2.3%, lagging behind manufacturing.

Capital Goods showed a 4.0% rise, indicating moderate investment activity.

Consumer Durables growth was quite weak at just 0.8%, suggesting subdued consumer demand for big-ticket items that year.

If you want, I can also:

break this down month-wise,

compare 2016‚Äì17 vs 2017‚Äì18, or

explain what was happening in the economy that led to these trends üìä

results.query: Compare Primary Goods and Capital goods for Maharashtra in 2023-24
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear comparison of Primary Goods vs Capital Goods for 2023‚Äì24, based on the Index of Industrial Production (IIP, base year 2011‚Äì12).

‚ö†Ô∏è Important context first:
The IIP does not provide state-wise data. So Maharashtra-specific figures are not available in the MoSPI IIP database.
What we can compare reliably is All-India performance, which is commonly used as a proxy when discussing industrial trends affecting major industrial states like Maharashtra.

Primary Goods vs Capital Goods (IIP, 2023‚Äì24)
Category	IIP Index (2011‚Äì12=100)	Growth Rate (%)
Primary Goods	147.7	6.1%
Capital Goods	106.6	6.3%
Interpretation (with Maharashtra in mind)
üîπ Primary Goods

Much higher index level (147.7) ‚Üí output well above the base year

Reflects strong production in basic/raw material industries

For Maharashtra: aligns with strength in metals, chemicals, petroleum, and basic manufacturing

üîπ Capital Goods

Lower index (106.6) ‚Üí still relatively close to base year levels

Slightly higher growth (6.3%) than Primary Goods

Indicates investment revival, machinery demand, and capacity expansion

Especially relevant for Maharashtra‚Äôs engineering, auto, electrical equipment, and industrial machinery hubs (Pune, Mumbai region, Aurangabad)

Big Picture Takeaway

Primary Goods show structural strength (high level, steady growth)

Capital Goods show cyclical momentum (lower base, but marginally faster growth)

Together, they suggest:

Stable industrial foundations

Gradual pickup in investment-led growth

If you want, I can also:

Compare 2022‚Äì23 vs 2023‚Äì24 trends

Link this to Maharashtra‚Äôs GSDP or manufacturing share

Convert this into a short exam-ready answer (UPSC / State PSC / Economics)

Just tell me üëç

results.query: Show me Electricity and Mining trends from 2015-16 to 2024-25
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clean, official MoSPI (IIP, base year 2011-12) snapshot of Electricity and Mining trends from 2015-16 to 2024-25, covering both Index levels and annual growth rates.

üìà Index of Industrial Production (IIP): Sectoral Trends
Mining
Year	Index	Growth (%)
2015-16	97.3	4.3
2016-17	102.5	5.3
2017-18	104.9	2.3
2018-19	107.9	2.9
2019-20	109.6	1.6
2020-21	101.0	-7.8
2021-22	113.3	12.2
2022-23	119.9	5.8
2023-24	128.9	7.5
2024-25	132.8	3.0
Electricity
Year	Index	Growth (%)
2015-16	133.8	5.7
2016-17	141.6	5.8
2017-18	149.2	5.4
2018-19	156.9	5.2
2019-20	158.4	1.0
2020-21	157.6	-0.5
2021-22	170.1	7.9
2022-23	185.2	8.9
2023-24	198.3	7.1
2024-25	208.6	5.2
üîç Key Takeaways

Electricity shows a strong, steady long-term rise, with the index jumping from 133.8 ‚Üí 208.6 over the decade.

Mining is more volatile, hit hard in 2020-21 (-7.8%), but rebounded sharply in 2021-22 (+12.2%).

Post-pandemic recovery is stronger and more consistent in Electricity than Mining.

Both sectors reached their highest index levels in 2024-25.

If you want, I can:

üìä plot these trends,

üìà compare them with Manufacturing, or

üß† link them to GDP / energy demand / infrastructure growth.

Just say the word.

results.query: Compare Manufacturing and General index performance during COVID years 2019-20, 2020-21, 2021-22
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clean comparison of Manufacturing vs General Index (IIP, Base 2011-12) during the COVID period, using annual MoSPI data for the years you asked about.

I‚Äôve focused only on the headline indices:

Manufacturing (overall) ‚Üí Manufacturing with blank sub-category

General Index ‚Üí Overall IIP

Index of Industrial Production (IIP): COVID Years Comparison
üìå 2019‚Äì20 (Pre-COVID shock)
Index	Level	Growth (%)
General Index	129.0	-0.8%
Manufacturing	129.6	-1.4%

Insight:
Both indices were already slowing before COVID hit. Manufacturing underperformed the General Index slightly.

üìå 2020‚Äì21 (COVID shock year)
Index	Level	Growth (%)
General Index	118.1	-8.4%
Manufacturing	117.2	-9.6%

Insight:
This was the worst year for both indices.

Manufacturing fell more sharply than the overall industrial sector.

Lockdowns, supply chain disruptions, and demand collapse hit factories hardest.

üìå 2021‚Äì22 (Recovery year)
Index	Level	Growth (%)
General Index	131.6	+11.4%
Manufacturing	131.0	+11.8%

Insight:
Strong rebound year:

Manufacturing outperformed the General Index in growth terms.

Pent-up demand, reopening, and export recovery drove the bounce-back.

üìä Overall Takeaways

Manufacturing is more volatile than the General Index:

Fell harder in 2020‚Äì21

Rebounded slightly stronger in 2021‚Äì22

General Index is more stable, cushioned by mining and electricity.

By 2021‚Äì22, both indices fully recovered to (and exceeded) pre-COVID levels.

If you want, I can:

Plot this as a trend chart

Compare Manufacturing vs Mining/Electricity

Break Manufacturing recovery by use-based sectors (capital goods, consumer durables, etc.)

results.query: What is the gap between Capital Goods and Consumer goods categories in 2016-17?
results.response_text:
Using the Index of Industrial Production (IIP), base year 2011‚Äì12, for 2016‚Äì17:

Capital Goods index: 101.5

Consumer Goods are split into:

Consumer Durables: 122.6

Consumer Non-durables: 126.5

Since MoSPI does not publish a single combined ‚ÄúConsumer Goods‚Äù index for this year, a simple way to express the gap is to compare Capital Goods with the average of Consumer Durables and Non-durables:

Average Consumer Goods index ‚âà 124.6

Gap (Consumer Goods ‚Äì Capital Goods) ‚âà 124.6 ‚àí 101.5 = ~23.1 index points

üìå Answer:
The gap between Capital Goods and Consumer Goods in 2016‚Äì17 is about 23 index points, with Consumer Goods performing significantly higher than Capital Goods.

If you want, I can also explain this gap in terms of growth rates or show how it changed over multiple years.
